metadata.title: JSON Configuration Syntax - Configuration Language
metadata.description:
In addition to the native syntax that is most commonly used with Packer,
the HCL language can also be expressed in a JSON-compatible syntax.

HCL2 templates
were first introduced as a beta feature into Packer version 1.5. As of v1.7,
HCL2 support is no longer in beta, and is the preferred way to write Packer
configuration. For the old-style stable configuration language see
`,mdx("a",e({parentName:"p"},{href:"/packer/docs/templates/legacy_json_templates"}),"template docs"),`. As of v1.6.2, you can

`,mdx("a",e({parentName:"p"},{href:"/packer/docs/commands/hcl2_upgrade"}),"hcl2_upgrade command"),".")),mdx("p",null,"Most Packer configurations are written in ",mdx("a",e({parentName:"p"},{href:"/packer/docs/templates/hcl_templates/syntax"}),`the native HCL
syntax`),`, which is designed to be easy for humans to read and
update.`),mdx("p",null,`Packer also supports an alternative syntax that is JSON-compatible. This
syntax is useful when generating portions of a configuration programmatically,
since existing JSON libraries can be used to prepare the generated
configuration files.`),mdx("p",null,`This syntax is not to be confused with the pre-version-1.5 "legacy" Packer
templates, which were exclusively JSON and follow a different format.`),mdx("p",null,`The JSON syntax is defined in terms of the native syntax. Everything that can
be expressed in native syntax can also be expressed in JSON syntax, but some
constructs are more complex to represent in JSON due to limitations of the
JSON grammar.`),mdx("p",null,"Packer expects native syntax for files named with a ",mdx("inlineCode",{parentName:"p"},".pkr.hcl"),` suffix, and JSON
syntax for files named with a `,mdx("inlineCode",{parentName:"p"},".pkr.json")," suffix. If you leave out the ",mdx("inlineCode",{parentName:"p"},".pkr"),`
portion of suffix, Packer will try to read your json file as a legacy Packer
template.`),mdx("p",null,`The low-level JSON syntax, just as with the native syntax, is defined in terms
of a specification called `,mdx("em",{parentName:"p"},"HCL"),`. It is not necessary to know all of the details
of HCL syntax or its JSON mapping in order to use Packer, and so this page
summarizes the most important differences between native and JSON syntax. If
you are interested, you can find a full definition of HCL's JSON syntax in `,mdx("a",e({parentName:"p"},{href:"https://github.com/hashicorp/hcl/blob/hcl2/hclsyntax/spec.md"}),`its

whose name represents the label for each `,mdx("inlineCode",{parentName:"p"},"provisioner"),` block. For block types
that expect multiple labels, this pattern of alternating array and object
nesting can be used for each additional level.`),mdx("p",null,"If a nested block type requires labels but the order does ",mdx("em",{parentName:"p"},"not"),` matter, you
may omit the array and provide just a single object whose property names
correspond to unique block labels. This is allowed as a shorthand for the above
for simple cases, but the alternating array and object approach is the most
general. We recommend using the most general form if systematically converting
from native syntax to JSON, to ensure that the meaning of the configuration is
preserved exactly.`),mdx("h3",e({},{id:"comment-properties"}),mdx("a",e({parentName:"h3"},{className:"__permalink-h",href:"#comment-properties","aria-label":"comment properties permalink"}),"\xBB"),"Comment Properties"),mdx("p",null,`Although we do not recommend hand-editing of JSON syntax configuration files

metadata.title: Packer by HashiCorp
metadata.description: Packer helps you create golden images for multiple platforms from a single source configuration.

alertBanner.text: Our community conference is taking place in San Francisco and online October 10-12.

integrationsConfig.description: A curated collection of official, partner, and community Packer Integrations.
